description:
Dasypus novemcinctus, commonly known as the nine-banded armadillo, is a species of armadillo found in North, Central, and South America. It is the only armadillo species found in the United States.

The nine-banded armadillo is a small to medium-sized mammal, typically measuring between 15 to 17 inches (38 to 43 cm) in length and weighing between 8 to 18 pounds (3.6 to 8.2 kg). It is characterized by its hard, bony carapace that is divided into nine distinct bands, which allow the animal to curl up into a ball for protection.

These armadillos are omnivorous, feeding on a variety of insects, small vertebrates, and plant matter. They are nocturnal and solitary, living in burrows or hollow logs. They are adaptable to a wide range of habitats, including grasslands, forests, and urban areas.

Reproduction in the nine-banded armadillo is unique, as the species exhibits obligate polyembryony, where a single fertilized egg divides into four genetically identical offspring. This results in the birth of four identical young, known as "pups."

The nine-banded armadillo is an important species in its ecosystem, serving as a food source for predators and contributing to the overall biodiversity of the regions it inhabits. It is also of interest to researchers due to its unique biology and adaptations to its environment.
